source.raw_text:
Jumping jacks are a full-body cardio exercise engaging calves, quads, hamstrings, glutes (lower body), deltoids, and shoulder muscles (upper body) for propulsion and arm movement, alongside core and hip stabilizers; the movement pattern involves rhythmic jumping (hip/knee/ankle extension) and arm abduction/adduction (raising/lowering arms), requiring coordination and working as a plyometric warm-up or conditioning exercise. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked: 

• Lower Body: Calves (gastrocnemius, soleus), Quadriceps (vastus muscles), Hamstrings, Glutes. 
• Upper Body: Shoulders (deltoids, supraspinatus), Arms (biceps/triceps stabilize). 
• Core & Hips: Core muscles, Hip abductors, Hip flexors for stability and movement control. [1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7]  

Movement Patterns (Phases): 

1. Starting Position: Standing with feet together, arms at sides. 
2. Upward/Outward (Propel/Abduction): 

    • Jumping feet out wide (hip and knee extension). 
    • Swinging arms overhead (shoulder abduction). 

3. Middle Position (Peak): Feet wide, arms overhead, body engaged. 
4. Downward/Inward (Return/Adduction): 

    • Jumping feet back together (hip and knee flexion, ankle dorsiflexion for landing). 
    • Bringing arms back down to sides (shoulder adduction). 

5. Rhythm: This cycle repeats continuously, making it a great plyometric and cardiovascular exercise. [1, 2, 5, 6, 7]  

*Citations:**

[1] https://www.webmd.com/fitness-exercise/how-to-do-jumping-jacks
[2] https://melmagazine.com/en-us/story/what-muscles-do-jumping-jacks-work
[3] https://sworkit.com/fitness-goals/exercise-spotlight-jumping-jacks

[5] https://squatwolf.com/blogs/fitness/jumping-jacks
